<0><0>User guide

The Atlas can be explored with the help of a Compass and moving along 3 different itineraries, each divided into 3 stages.

<2>In every part of the Atlas, the<1> Compass allows users to have 3 guide visualizations always close at hand:<3><0><0>a concise map of the author’s literary career (<1>Time and Works)<1>the reconstruction of the publishing history of his short stories (<1>Flows of the Stories)<2>the representation of the writer’s mental library (<1>The Archipelago of Names)<4>The <2>3 itineraries we decided to follow are:<5><0><0>doubt, considered one of the main driving forces of Calvino’s writing<1>space, which allows an exploration of his works through the mapping of all his locations<2>form, which examines the essential problem of the plot<6><0>Each itinerary is furthermore developed into 3 stages:<1><0>the first stage (<1>phenomenon) introduces the most concrete and tangible aspect of the itinerary<1>the second stage (<1>process) attempts to grasp the dynamic behind each phenomenon<2>the third stage (<1>problem) examines the main issue leading to each phenomenon, starting the process <7>Each visualization in the Atlas has a key and an explanation (composed of three sections: What is it?, How does it work?, Reading tips) on the right side of the page, useful for learning how to read the visualization.<8>Each itinerary also has 3 in-depth analyses, one for each stage, which go into a deeper study of a number of research aspects emerged from the main visualizations.<9>The main research was conducted over Calvino’s entire body of work and was based on the Romanzi e raccontiedition, directed by Claudio Milanini, edited by Mario Berenghi and Bruno Falcetto (Milano, Mondadori, 3 volumes, 1991, 1992 and 1994, referenced from now on as RR, followed by volume and page number). We have been granted free use of the digital format by Mondadori in order to compile the datasets used to create the visualizations. Whenever the visualization is based on a selection of works, it is clearly stated.

Although this has been a cooperative work, each of the three researchers of the University of Geneva’s literature team has specifically developed one itinerary, as follows:

<11><0>Doubt itinerary: Margherita Parigini
<4>Space itinerary: Virginia Giustetto
<8>Form itinerary: Valeria Cavalloro

L’Atlante è stato scritto in italiano e tradotto in inglese, affinché fosse disponibile in una doppia versione. I titoli delle opere appaiono sempre in lingua originale. Per quanto riguarda le citazioni, laddove non è diversamente specificato, la traduzione è nostra.
